Project Number: 42368 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2010 
 
 
 
Strengthening Institutional Capacity to Compile 
and Analyze Financial Soundness Indicators  
for Investment Climate Assessment  
(Financed by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund 
under the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since the late 1990s, a number of developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) has experienced financial crises that have often severely disrupted 
investment and economic activity. The often significant costs of these crises have highlighted 
the need to develop and analyze a set of financial soundness indicators (FSIs) that can help 
policy makers identify the strengths and vulnerabilities in their countries' financial systems and 
take preventive action to avert a crisis or at least minimize its effects. As the need for FSIs is 
reinforced by the current global economic turmoil originating in the subprime mortgage crisis in 
the United States, FSIs can also provide an additional set of statistics with which potential 
investors  can  assess  the  investment  climate  in  DMCs  before  committing  to  investment 
strategies and decisions. Higher investments in these countries will enhance economic growth 
and interregional trade. Moreover, financial sector development is one of the five core areas in 
ADB’s Strategy 2020.1 The development of high-quality and internationally comparable FSIs 
and their analysis in participating DMCs will help in monitoring the state of the finance sector in 
them and in ensuring that efforts to develop the sector are effective.  
 
2.  This  regional  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  participating 
DMCs  to  strengthen  their  institutional  and  statistical  capacity  to  routinely  collect,  compile, 
disseminate, and analyze internationally comparable FSIs. The compilation of FSIs will follow 
the recommendations and guidelines in the Financial Soundness Indicators Compilation Guide 
published by the International Monetary Fund (IMF).2 In conceptualizing the TA, discussions 
were held with the IMF and within ADB on which DMCs to include and the appropriate way to 
plan the assistance to avoid any duplication of aid. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.3 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  FSIs4 register the current financial health and soundness of the financial institutions in a 
country, as well as of corporations and households. They include both aggregated data on 
individual institutions and indicators that are representative of the markets in which the financial 
institutions operate. FSIs are computed and disseminated to support macro-prudential analysis, 
which  is  the  assessment  and  surveillance  of  the  strengths  and  vulnerabilities  of  financial 
systems, with the aim of enhancing financial stability and policy making and, especially, of 
limiting the likelihood of financial system failure. 
 
4.  The need for a set of FSIs to assess the strengths and weaknesses of financial systems 
has intensified in recent years in view of the financial crises that have hit many developing 
countries. Shortly after the Asian financial crisis in 1997, ADB helped central banks of selected 
DMCs to identify, compile, and interpret about 30 additional monetary and financial statistics 
and macro-prudential indicators in an attempt to prevent another crisis. This was followed by 
work on early warning systems, with a prototype developed to detect region-wide economic and 
financial vulnerabilities among members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the 
People’s Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea. Another TA project built on these 
                                                 
1 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
2 IMF. 2006. Financial Soundness Indicators: Compilation Guide. Washington, DC. 
3 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 November 2010. 
4 Distinguished from financial conditions indexes, which measure financial shocks or shifts in financial conditions, that 
influence or predict future economic activity.

2  
initiatives by modifying the prototype into country-specific early warning systems that can be 
operated  by  government  agencies.  Another  project  aims  to  develop  an  FSI  database  for 
selected Asian developing economies.5 The TA complements these efforts and expands the 
research frontier through practical applications. 
 
5.  Policy makers and investors require information upon which to base their decisions. In 
this period of globalization, however, currently available country-specific indicators constrain 
cross-country comparisons. To address this issue, the IMF has proposed a common set of 
statistics described in the Financial Soundness Indicators Compilation Guide, which defines a 
list of core FSIs to be compiled by countries and another list of encouraged FSIs (Appendix 2). 
The guide provides information, recommendations, and advice on the conceptual framework; 
concepts and definitions; and sources and techniques to use when compiling and disseminating 
core and encouraged FSIs. It also defines the types of financial institutions, explains in detail 
accounting  rules  and  the  valuation  of  instruments,  and  provides  conceptual  advice  and 
guidance  on  individual  line  items  in  income  and  expenditure  accounts  and  balance  sheet 
accounts, from which the underlying series used to compute many FSIs can be obtained. 
Concepts of the preferred approaches to aggregation and consolidation are explained, and 
information is provided on how to develop the metadata to disseminate with the FSIs and 
enable users to make cross-country comparisons. In addition, as each country has its unique 
financial structure that affects the range of FSIs that may be computed and their assessment, 
the guide outlines a list of structural indicators to be compiled in addition to the set of core and 
encouraged FSIs. The structural indicators provide some indication of the types of markets that 
exist in a country and their stage of development. 
 
6.  The guide notes that FSIs are a new body of economic statistics that arise from various 
influences and that compiling FSIs is likely to require relatively skilled staff in compiling agencies. 
Accordingly, the IMF conducted a coordinated compilation exercise (CCE) from 2004 to 2007 in 
which 62 participating countries developed their capacity to compile FSIs that are important to 
surveilling  their  financial  systems,  promoting  the  cross-country  comparability  of  FSIs, 
coordinating the efforts of national authorities to compile FSIs, and disseminating FSIs compiled 
during the CCE, together with the detailed metadata, to improve transparency. The CCE was 
implemented through a combination of technical advice and meetings. Participating countries 
were requested to compile all the core FSIs and at least some of the encouraged ones using the 
standard reporting forms prepared by the IMF. The IMF intends to conduct similar exercises in 
the future, so the TA comes at a very opportune time, as it will enable ADB to learn from the 
valuable lessons that emerged from the CCE and help it to coordinate with the IMF in terms of 
modalities and scope of assistance to avoid duplication.  
 
7.  The selection of recipient DMCs for this assistance rests on geographical diversity, 
recipient country interest and level of economic and financial development, what the TA can 
achieve  given  its  funding  and  time  frame,  and  the  potential  for  complementarity  with  IMF 
efforts.6 The FSIs compiled in the four target DMCs under the TA will provide a common set of 
statistics that can be used for comparison with those of other countries in their subregions that

3
already use the IMF FSIs framework.7 Analysis of the data will focus on cross-country and 
interregional comparisons. The improved comparability arising from the use of this common set 
of statistics will help investors to better assess the investment climate and conditions in the four 
target DMCs. Any resultant increase in investments in these four DMCs will help to boost their 
economic  development  and  integration  into  their  subregions  through,  for  example,  trade. 
Moreover, the higher degree of economic integration and faster economic growth which will be 
achieved in these three subregions may have other positive effects in the form of greater 
interregional trade.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA will help the four participating DMCs–Bangladesh, Georgia, Sri Lanka, and Viet 
Nam–strengthen their institutional and statistical capacity to routinely collect, compile, analyze, 
and  disseminate  internationally  comparable  FSIs.  The  availability  of  better-quality  and 
internationally comparable FSIs will help to improve the surveillance of financial systems in 
participating DMCs. The FSIs compiled and analyzed in participating DMCs are expected to be 
used in financial surveillance, assessment of the investment climate, and policy making.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will be implemented through (i) consulting services; (ii) country consultations; (iii) 
support for data collection and compilation; (iv) in-country training; (v) workshops, seminars, and 
conferences; (vi) sector studies and data analysis; and (vii) knowledge dissemination. The 
scope of the TA surpasses the two objectives of the IMF CCE: core data compilation and 
dissemination. Where appropriate, ADB will coordinate with the IMF to streamline support for 
participating DMCs.8 The IMF will also be consulted when more complicated technical issues 
arise during project implementation. 
 
10.  The TA will work with the lead agency nominated by the participating DMC as the FSI 
country coordinator. The lead agency in each participating DMC will coordinate with other 
agencies  in  collecting  and  compiling  FSIs  and  with  ADB  in  implementing  the  various 
components of the TA. The lead agency will be responsible for (i) compiling time-series data on 
the FSIs (and, where appropriate, structural indicators) and the underlying data series and 
detailed metadata according to the guidelines and format of the IMF's reporting form for FSIs; (ii) 
computing and disseminating the FSIs; and (iii) sustaining the activity after TA completion. It will 
prepare an inventory of current practices in collecting, compiling, and disseminating FSIs and 
make appropriate recommendations for improvements in consultation with ADB and the IMF. 
                                                 
7 The four DMCs that have been consulted and have not yet participated in the IMF CCE are Bangladesh, Georgia, 
Sri Lanka, and Viet Nam. The other countries that use the IMF FSIs framework include Armenia and Kazakhstan in 
Central and West Asia; India in South Asia; and Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Singapore in Southeast 
Asia.  
8 Discussions with the IMF reveal that TA to countries will be similar to that provided during the CCE. Globally, the 
IMF will provide all countries with (i) standard FSI templates for use in reporting FSIs to the IMF, (ii) guidance on 
how to complete the FSI templates, (iii) guidelines and assistance on how to use an internet-based integrated 
correspondence system developed by the IMF for reporting FSIs to the IMF, and (iv) training on methodology for 
compiling FSIs and procedures for constructing specific FSIs. To resolve country-specific issues, IMF economists 
correspond via e-mail and telephone with FSI country coordinators and include FSI components in monetary 
statistics missions to countries. The IMF will provide advice and recommendations if there is a need to develop or 
explore new data sources for compiling FSIs.

4  
The lead agency will also prepare a compendium of FSIs based primarily on information that is 
already available.9  
 
11.  All the core FSIs should be computed for use in the analysis, together with as many of 
the encouraged FSIs as can be computed. As far as possible, only existing data sources should 
be used. It is preferable that no additional indicators be introduced, as the aim is to compile the 
core and encouraged indicators and, where appropriate, the structural indicators in the IMF 
guide. However, if new sources must be explored to get data for missing core indicators, the TA 
will support, to the extent possible within a reasonable time frame, the collection of additional 
basic data. Limited equipment support will be provided for this activity as allowed in the current 
guidelines for the use of the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund.  
 
12.  In each DMC, international consultants will prepare a handbook of methods for collecting 
and compiling FSIs that will incorporate information from the compendia. They will work with the 
lead agency in analyzing the results of the compilation to strengthen institutional capacity in the 
country. They will prepare working papers on the key findings of the TA and apply the findings 
to  improve  the  surveillance  of  the  financial  sector.  Studies  will  be  carried  out  to  better 
understand  national and regional finance sector issues affecting countries in the region that use 
FSIs to gauge the investment climate and facilitate policy making. The key outputs of the TA will 
be the compendia of FSIs, handbook, working papers on data analysis, and financial sector 
assessments and investment climate studies. The common output of ADB and the IMF will be 
the DMCs’ FSI indicators, underlying data series, metadata, and inventory of current practices.  
 
13.  The TA will support a number of workshops and in-country training programs.10 The first 
will be an inception workshop to discuss activities and their timetable, the inventory of current 
practices in the compilation of FSIs in participating DMCs, a draft conceptual framework for the 
development of FSIs and compendia of them, the preparation of FSIs and underlying data 
series and detailed metadata, and areas for analysis. Because the compilation of FSIs will likely 
involve  several  national  agencies,  in-country  training  workshops  will  be  organized  to  train 
agency staff on how to compile and calculate FSIs and the underlying metadata according to 
the guide and the standard reporting forms to ensure that the agencies are able to collect the 
data needed to compute the FSIs during the TA and after its completion.11  Workshops will 
promote the use and analysis of FSIs among policy makers and other data users and provide 
venues to discuss the results of the studies. Toward the end of the TA, a concluding workshop 
will discuss its results.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent. It will be financed on a grant basis by 
the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund12 under the Regional Cooperation and Integration 
Financing Partnership Facility and be administered by ADB. Appendix 3 provides cost estimates 
and the financing plan. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with the Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
                                                 
9  If the lead agency does not have the highly specialized and technical skills necessary to successfully implement the 
TA, national consultants will be recruited for this task. 
10 The training programs will be conducted in the DMCs in addition to the IMF’s global 2-week FSI courses held in 
IMF regional training centers.  
11 Where appropriate, the IMF will be invited to send resource persons to participate in workshops, and the training 
will be scheduled to coincide with IMF missions to the country. 
12 Established by the Government of Japan.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, with the focal point being the Economics 
and Research Department's Office of the Chief Economist, which will also administer the budget 
for  the  TA.  The  ADB  project  officer  will  implement  the  various  components  of  the  TA  in 
consultation with participating DMCs and consultants. There will be regular communications 
with the IMF to ensure no overlap of activities and, to the extent possible, that activities are 
synchronized. 
 
16.  To  promote  ownership  of  the  data  production  and  ensure  its  sustainability,  the 
Development Indicators and Policy Research Division will work with each lead agency under a 
memorandum of understanding specifying the nature and scope of ADB's assistance and the 
obligations of the lead agency. The memorandum of understanding will be prepared and signed 
before the actual compilation of FSIs begins. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 36 months starting in January 2011. It will finance up to 
8 person-months of international consulting services and 15 person-months of national. The 
consultancy requirements are (i) one international financial statistics consultant (2.00 person-
months, intermittent); (ii) four international financial sector consultants (1.50 person-months 
each, intermittent); (iii) four national financial statistics consultants (3.25 person-months each, 
intermittent); (iii) one national copyediting consultant (1 person-month, intermittent); and (iv) one 
national  graphic  design  consultant  (1  person-month,  intermittent).  Provision  for  resource 
persons, including ADB staff, is included. The TA is expected to be completed in December 
2013. 
 
18.  ADB will engage all consultants as individuals in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for 
consultants  is  in  Appendix  4.  Procurement  will  be  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). All equipment purchased using 
the TA budget will be turned over to participating DMCs upon the completion of the TA.  
 
19.  The TA will be implemented, supervised, and monitored following Investment Climate 
Facilitation Fund implementation and reporting guidelines. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility for Strengthening Institutional Capacity to Compile 
and Analyze Financial Soundness Indicators for Investment Climate Assessment, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 4  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Financial Statistics Consultant (2 person-months, intermittent) 
 
1.  The consultant should have a strong background in economics and/or statistics and 
extensive knowledge of how financial statistics are compiled in the Asia and Pacific and be 
familiar with the recommendations of the Financial Soundness Indicators Compilation Guide of 
the International Monetary Fund (IMF).1 The consultant is expected to provide the necessary 
guidance  and  supervision  to  national  consultants  and  participating  developing  member 
countries (DMCs) and work in a cooperative manner with them.  
 
2.  In particular, under the guidance and supervision of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
project officer and in consultation with the participating DMCs, the consultant will perform the 
following tasks: 
(i)  Conduct  a  review  of  the  experience  of  DMCs  in  collecting,  compiling,  and 
disseminating financial soundness indicators (FSIs) in consultation, if necessary, 
with the IMF. 
(ii)  Guide the participating DMCs and national consultants in preparing an inventory 
of  current  practices  in  collecting,  compiling,  and  disseminating  FSIs  and 
recommendations for improvements. 
(iii)  Prepare an outline of the framework for developing FSIs. 
(iv)  Work with the participating DMCs and national consultants to identify which FSIs 
can be produced and their frequency given the resource constraints (all core 
FSIs and some encouraged FSIs should be produced). 
(v)  Provide technical advice and guidance to the participating DMCs and national 
consultants in the compilation of FSIs (and structural indicators when possible) 
and underlying data series and metadata according to the recommendations of 
the IMF guide and reporting form format. 
(vi)  Prepare a detailed outline of and format for the compendia of FSIs for the use of 
participating DMCs, including necessary preparation guidelines and instructions. 
(vii)  Provide technical guidance to participating DMCs and national consultants in the 
preparation of the compendia of FSIs. 
(viii)  Review the work produced by participating DMCs and national consultants. 
(ix)  Work with the project officer to prepare a working paper on methods of compiling 
FSIs and key results for publication. 
(x)  Prepare a handbook of methods for collecting, compiling, and disseminating FSIs 
in the context of Asia and the Pacific, with specific reference to participating 
DMCs. 
(xi)  Assist  in  the  conduct  of  inception,  in-country,  user–producer,  and  other 
workshops.   
(xii)  Conduct training workshops in participating DMCs. 
(xiii)  Perform other tasks as assigned by ADB.   
 
B.  International Financial Sector Consultants (four consultants, 1.5 person-months 
each, intermittent) 
 
3.  Working with staff of the Economics and Research Department responsible for this 
project,  the  international  experts  will  be  responsible  for  conceptualizing,  designing,  and 
undertaking research on the issues concerned in this technical assistance. The experts should 
                                                 
1 IMF. 2006. Financial Soundness Indicators: Compilation Guide. Washington, DC.

12      Appendix 4 
have (i) a doctorate in a relevant field; (ii) expert knowledge of finance sector development and 
measurement  issues  in  developing  Asia  and  the  Pacific;  (iii)  proven  capacity  for  both 
quantitative and policy-oriented analysis; and (iv) proven capacity to synthesize complex issues 
and  identify  key  policy  messages  for  policy makers,  development  partners,  and  other  key 
stakeholders.  
 
4.  In  particular,  with  the  guidance  and  supervision  of  the  ADB  project  officer  and  in 
consultation with participating DMCs, the consultant will:  
(i)  conceptualize, design, and conduct research on the research theme identified; 
(ii)  implement revisions as required for final publication; 
(iii)  participate in technical assistance-related activities like conferences and policy 
dialogues; 
(iv)  provide other research and project-related inputs as required; and 
(v)  perform other tasks as assigned by ADB. 
 
C.  National Financial Statistics Consultants (four consultants, 3.25 person-months each, 
intermittent) 
5.  The consultants should have strong backgrounds in economics and/or statistics and 
extensive  practical  knowledge  of  how  financial  statistics  are  compiled  in  their  respective 
countries. They should have a working knowledge of the recommendations of the IMF's FSIs 
guide and be proficient in the use of statistical software packages. The consultants are expected 
to work in a cooperative manner with the international consultant and the agencies of their 
countries. Extensive prior working experience in the statistics or data collection units of their 
countries’ central bank is highly desirable. 
 
6.  In particular, under the guidance and supervision of the ADB project officer and the 
international consultant and in consultation with their respective countries, the consultants will: 
(i)  prepare  an  inventory  of  current  practices  in  collecting,  compiling,  and 
disseminating FSIs and make recommendations for improvements;  
(ii)  identify which FSIs can be produced and their frequency given the resource 
constraints (all core FSIs and some encouraged FSIs should be produced); 
(iii)  compile FSIs (and, where appropriate, structural indicators) and underlying data 
series and metadata according to the recommendations of the IMF FSIs guide 
and format of its reporting forms; 
(iv)  prepare a compendium of FSIs for their respective participating DMCs; 
(v)  assist in the conduct of inception and regional workshops; 
(vi)  assist in the conduct of training and user–producer workshops in their respective 
participating DMCs;  
(vii)  provide inputs to the preparation of the working paper on methods for compiling 
FSIs and key findings and the handbook of methods for collecting, compiling, and 
disseminating FSIs; and 
(viii)  perform other tasks as assigned by ADB. 
 
D.  National Copyeditor (1 person-month, intermittent) 
7.  The editor will be responsible for copyediting the handbook and compendia of FSIs. He 
or she must possess strong ability to edit technical documents using Adobe Creative Suite and 
Microsoft Word and Excel.

Appendix 4  13 
8.  In particular, under the guidance and supervision of the ADB project officer, the editor 
will: 
(i)  edit the handbook and compendia to ensure that they adhere to ADB style and 
usage and conform to high publication standards,  
(ii)  copyread and proofread the handbook and compendia, and 
(iii)  perform other tasks as assigned by ADB. 
 
E.  National Desktop Publishing Specialist (1 person-month, intermittent) 
9.  The  desktop  publishing  specialist  will  be  responsible  for  laying  out  text,  encoding 
corrections,  redoing the  layout,  and  formatting  graphic  elements  of the  handbook  and  the 
compendia of FSIs, including refining the web versions.   
 
10.  In particular, under the guidance and supervision of the ADB project officer, the editor 
will: 
(i)  lay out the handbook and the compendia and ensure that they conform to high 
publication standards,  
(ii)  encode corrections in the handbook and the compendia based on corrections 
received from Development Indicators and Policy Research Division (ERDI) staff 
and consultants, 
(iii)  prepare the final layout of the handbook and compendia, 
(iv)  encode final text and graphical corrections from ERDI and consultants, 
(v)  deliver the final artwork of the handbook and the compendia to ERDI for final 
offset printing, 
(vi)  deliver the web-ready and pre-flighted consolidated PDF of the handbook and 
compendia to ERDI, and 
(vii)  perform other tasks as assigned by ADB.
